citations.narrative:
Upon being asked if she was refusing inspection, the licensee became verbally abusive to the lead inspector. She
questioned the inspector's intelligence, she accused the inspector of leaking information to animal rights groups, she
accused the inspector of lying, she yelled expletives and insults at the inspector. She was gesturing and yelling
aggressively and came within a foot of the inspector's face and body when other APHIS officials put their body in between
and told her she needed to step away. After being given time to calm down, the licensee continued to hurl accusations
and insults at the inspector before confirming that she was refusing inspection.
APHIS officials must be able to carry out their duties without interference or threat of harm, abuse, or harassment in order
to ensure the welfare of regulated animals. Correct immediately by allowing inspectors to safely conduct inspections.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
APHIS officials arrived at the property at approximately 10:45am. After several minutes, the licensee arrived from the
direction of her home. She appeared agitated and stated that she was not doing an inspection today. We asked if she was
refusing inspection. At first she responded yes but then asked if we could come back after lunch because she was short
staffed and needed time to calm down. We stated that we couldn't do that and needed to do an inspection right now. She
became verbally abusive to the inspectors and was asked to step away. She and another APHIS official walked a short
distance away to speak and calm down. Upon returning to inspectors at approximately 11:45am, she appeared calmer so
we again asked if we could conduct an inspection and she told us to get off her property. We asked if she was refusing
and she said yes.
Allowing inspectors to conduct inspections is a requirement of all licensed facilities under the Animal Welfare Act.
Refusing inspection inhibits the regulatory process and prevents inspectors from assessing animal health and welfare,
and prevents the Secretary from fulfilling his obligation to enforce the Animal Welfare Act. Correct immediately by allowing
inspectors to conduct inspections during normal business hours without harassment or interference in the inspection
process by the licensee.
This inspection was refused by the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
